Jack Works: why not use the contract from DOM? As in you hand the abort signal some set of steps to run upon aborting

content.body:
> <@annevk:mozilla.org> Jack Works: why not use the contract from DOM? As in you hand the abort signal some set of steps to run upon aborting

DOM contract uses async callback which we want to avoid
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:mozilla.org
Jack Works: why not use the contract from DOM? As in you hand the abort signal some set of steps to run upon aborting
DOM contract uses async callback which we want to avoid

content.body: And it's more dubious if we write ? Get(signal, "addEventListener")
Jack Works: that would be dubious, but there's a non-script-exposed mechanism which is what I was referring to
content.formatted_body: Jack Works: that would be dubious, but there's a non-script-exposed mechanism which is what I was referring to

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Jack Works: that would be dubious, but there's a non-script-exposed mechanism which is what I was referring to
Jack Works: that would be dubious, but there's a non-script-exposed mechanism which is what I was referring to

content.body: And if you want this to be useful beyond this API you'd need some kind of callback-style thing I'd think, not everything can lazily check whether the signal is aborted
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: And if you want this to be useful beyond this API you'd need some kind of callback-style thing I'd think, not everything can lazily check whether the signal is aborted

content.body: Yeah I agree. Since it will be much harder to design a general signal (with callback) I think it's somehow ok since we don't have anywhere else that requires a signal
I've wanted to push cancellation forward, but I keep getting the same response from Domenic and he seems to have no interest in discussing the point further.
content.formatted_body: I've wanted to push cancellation forward, but I keep getting the same response from Domenic and he seems to have no interest in discussing the point further.

content.body: There are multiple issues with AbortController that make it not ideal for inclusion in ECMA-262

> <@jackworks:matrix.org> Yeah I agree. Since it will be much harder to design a general signal (with callback) I think it's somehow ok since we don't have anywhere else that requires a signal

There are other places where it would be useful
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @jackworks:matrix.org
Yeah I agree. Since it will be much harder to design a general signal (with callback) I think it's somehow ok since we don't have anywhere else that requires a signal
There are other places where it would be useful

content.body: I think Domenic gave a reasonable way forward that Jack Works seems to be pursuing? You make the signal host-supplied and define a compatible not-script-visible contract with it.
content.formatted_body: I think Domenic gave a reasonable way forward that Jack Works seems to be pursuing? You make the signal host-supplied and define a compatible not-script-visible contract with it.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: I think Domenic gave a reasonable way forward that Jack Works seems to be pursuing? You make the signal host-supplied and define a compatible not-script-visible contract with it.
I think Domenic gave a reasonable way forward that Jack Works seems to be pursuing? You make the signal host-supplied and define a compatible not-script-visible contract with it.

content.body: Wasn't part of Jack Works concern that AbortSignal is an async callback? IIRC, AbortSignal also uses EventTarget for abort registration, which holds onto the callback even after the signal is aborted, which can prevent GC
content.formatted_body: Wasn't part of Jack Works concern that AbortSignal is an async callback? IIRC, AbortSignal also uses EventTarget for abort registration, which holds onto the callback even after the signal is aborted, which can prevent GC

content.body: You can add a callback to an AbortSignal but you can also lazily check whether it's aborted. I think Jack Works said that for their thing the latter is sufficient.
content.formatted_body: You can add a callback to an AbortSignal but you can also lazily check whether it's aborted. I think Jack Works said that for their thing the latter is sufficient.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: You can add a callback to an AbortSignal but you can also lazily check whether it's aborted. I think Jack Works said that for their thing the latter is sufficient.
You can add a callback to an AbortSignal but you can also lazily check whether it's aborted. I think Jack Works said that for their thing the latter is sufficient.

content.body: The callback is a spec-concept btw, it's not exposed. Any event listeners would be user code.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: The callback is a spec-concept btw, it's not exposed. Any event listeners would be user code.

content.body: I was able to make a version of `@esfx/async-canceltoken` that works with the DOM but uses my proposed cancellation API, so I may end up going with Domenic's suggestion despite my reservations
content.formatted_body: I was able to make a version of @esfx/async-canceltoken that works with the DOM but uses my proposed cancellation API, so I may end up going with Domenic's suggestion despite my reservations

content.body: But I find it very unfortunate we can't have an actual cancellation primitive in the core language because of this
(my "compatible" CancelToken just creates an AbortSignal and repoints the prototype so that it has the correct internal slots the DOM expects)
It doesn't seem inconceivable for JS to embrace EventTarget one day, but I personally don't get super excited about artificial boundaries imposed by standards bodies ðŸ™‚
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: It doesn't seem inconceivable for JS to embrace EventTarget one day, but I personally don't get super excited about artificial boundaries imposed by standards bodies ðŸ™‚

content.body: And, honestly, that might be an alternative to a host hook as well...
content.formatted_body: And, honestly, that might be an alternative to a host hook as well...

content.body: It's not just EventTarget, it's the exceptions that are thrown as well. I had the same issue looking into bringing a portion of the Web crypto api to TC39
content.formatted_body: It's not just EventTarget, it's the exceptions that are thrown as well. I had the same issue looking into bringing a portion of the Web crypto api to TC39

content.body: I'd like to bring a slew of async coordination primitive proposals to committee as well, but they need a cancellation primitive to be useful.
content.formatted_body: I'd like to bring a slew of async coordination primitive proposals to committee as well, but they need a cancellation primitive to be useful.

content.body: About 70% of `@esfx/*` are prototypes and proofs-of-concept for existing and future proposals
content.formatted_body: About 70% of @esfx/* are prototypes and proofs-of-concept for existing and future proposals

content.body:
> <@rbuckton:matrix.org> There are multiple issues with AbortController that make it not ideal for inclusion in ECMA-262

Yes. I cannot bring it into the language, but the massive proxy revocation needs a "revoke controller". The author of this proposal wants to add a synchronous revoke controller that is only used for Proxy revocation, but I don't want to have many different styles of controllers in the language meanwhile in the Host.

This is my answer, I didn't add it, but borrow it from the host
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @rbuckton:matrix.org
There are multiple issues with AbortController that make it not ideal for inclusion in ECMA-262

Yes. I cannot bring it into the language, but the massive proxy revocation needs a "revoke controller". The author of this proposal wants to add a synchronous revoke controller that is only used for Proxy revocation, but I don't want to have many different styles of controllers in the language meanwhile in the Host.

This is my answer, I didn't add it, but borrow it from the host

content.body:
> <@annevk:mozilla.org> The callback is a spec-concept btw, it's not exposed. Any event listeners would be user code.

Yes. In our case it is enough. Once aborted, the engine can revoke and GC all proxies.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:mozilla.org
The callback is a spec-concept btw, it's not exposed. Any event listeners would be user code.
Yes. In our case it is enough. Once aborted, the engine can revoke and GC all proxies.

content.body:
> <@jackworks:matrix.org> I heard EventTarget is heavily connected to the whole DOM stuff...

It's pretty easy to implement in a DOM-less environment. We do it in Deno, and Node does it too. There is just no bubbling then.
